history.content: I can't even think where to start with this one. Let me get back to you tomorrow.

children.subject:
I recommend you check the legal paperwork that you sign when you sign up as a TA; and check the paperwork that you sign when you sign on as an employee for the company.  That will tell you the legal obligations you are getting yourself into, and you can check whether they are compatible.  For instance, check whether you are asked to sign a patent assignment form when you are hired for either position.

Links on intellectual property at UC: http://www.ucop.edu/research-policy-analysis-coordination/policies-guidance/intellectual-property-ex/index.html, http://www.ucop.edu/research-policy-analysis-coordination/policies-guidance/intellectual-property-ex/intellectual-property-as-a-student-at-the-university-of-california.html, http://www.ucop.edu/research-policy-analysis-coordination/policies-guidance/intellectual-property-ex/intellectual-property-as-a-student-at-the-university-of-california-faq.html, http://copyright.universityofcalifornia.edu/ownership/works-created-at-uc.html, http://vcresearch.berkeley.edu/research-policies/intellectual-property.

history.content:
I'm not sure if this is the right place to post this, but I was planning on working part time this semester for a company I'll be working for full time once I graduate. I'll be doing this at the same time I have an appointment as a TA, and was wondering if there are any legal complications around IP ownership that I should be concerned about? I understand that the staff on here may not be able to give legal advice, but in that case could you direct me to the resources that I should utilize to figure this out?

Thanks!
history.subject: Working part time while also being a TA
